awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type I: Cornell I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project establishes an I-Corps Site at Cornell University. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants.  The Cornell I-Corps Site represents a signature project of the institution's new Center for Technology Translation (CTT). The CTT serves as a central hub for entrepreneurship, innovation, product design, and prototyping education, all based on the Lean Launch Pad method. The Cornell Site integrates activities from the College of Business, College of Engineering, and Center for Technology Licensing, ultimately leading to synergistic benefits to an already thriving entrepreneurial ecosystem.

There are several strengths that characterize Cornell's I-Corps Site: it connects to the upper New York state business incubator ecosystem, and adds new components; they seek to include women, the disabled and under-represented groups in their teams and have a solid plan to do so; existing connections to regional businesses are strong; Cornell's Site has substantial campus financial support and experienced leadership; innovation and entrepreneurship programs are well organized and integrated with each other; and, the existence of an I-Corps Site at Cornell is likely to impact the regional commercialization ecosystem.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The NSF I-Corps™ Site at Cornell University hosted 44 I-Corps regional courses designed to help university researchers combine their strong technical and scientific knowledge with an entrepreneurial mindset, with the goal of discovering new technologies that can be developed for market. The Cornell I-Corps Site team focused on engaging Cornell’s large community of esteemed STEM faculty and deep tech researchers in I-Corps programming, on building strong partnerships and I-Corps brand recognition, and on broadening participation in I-Corps among underrepresented minorities including women, people of color, and people with disabilities. Efforts to broaden participation led to the development of customized regional I-Corps courses in partnership with Women Entrepreneurs (WE) Cornell, Cornell Black Entrepreneurs in Training, and the National GEM Consortium. In 2022, I-Corps has become known as the gold standard at Cornell for introducing deep technology researchers to entrepreneurship. 

By working closely with the Upstate New York (UNY) I-Corps Node, the Cornell I-Corps Site was able to utilize a strong existing I-Corps regional course curriculum, program delivery infrastructure, and instructor training program to stand up its I-Corps programming at Cornell quickly and to run it efficiently. 347 research teams participated in regional I-Corps course hosted by the Cornell I-Corps Site. 15 Cornell-affiliated instructors were trained to teach the regional I-Corps program, and 5 were also trained and certified by NSF as Core I-Corps instructors for the national I-Corps Teams program.  

To encourage the continuation of customer discovery activities, the Cornell I-Corps Site used most of its funding for participant support microgrant awards of up to $3,000 per regional team. 160 Site funding microgrants were awarded to qualified Cornellians who participated in I-Corps regional courses at Cornell University. 48 teams from Cornell went on to complete the NSF I-Corps Teams national program. 25 of those national teams included an I-Corps Mentor provided by the Cornell I-Corps Site. 

 


Last Modified: 07/27/2022
Modified by: Tom Schryver
